Title: Florilegia Syriaca: The Intercultural Dissemination of Greek Christian Thought in Syriac and Arabic in the First Millennium CE

This project, Florilegia Syriaca, seeks to illuminate the little-known cultural mediation of Syriac Christianity in the transmission of Greek Christian thought to Arabic-speaking communities during the first millennium CE. By focusing on the metamorphoses of Greek Christian thought in Syriac and Arabic, this project aims to define the religious identity of Syriac Christians and create open-access digital editions of Syriac florilegia, a genre of anthologies that played a crucial role in the dissemination of Christian knowledge.

Through the production of florilegia, this project will study the writings of Syriac and Christian Arabic authors, shedding light on the cultural dynamics of Late Antiquity and the role of patristic Christianity as a bridge between the intellectual history of Europe and the Middle East. The project's groundbreaking endeavors include the creation of digital editions of Syriac florilegia of the 8th-10th centuries and the study of neglected writings of Syriac and Christian Arabic authors of the 8th-11th centuries.

The expected research outcomes will significantly improve our understanding of the cultural dynamics of Late Antiquity, the role of patristic Christianity, and the preservation of endangered cultural heritage of Syriac Christians. Ultimately, this project will enhance our comprehension of Europe's current religious discourses and contribute to the preservation of a vital part of our shared cultural heritage.

Title: Florilegia Syriaca: The Intercultural Dissemination of Greek Christian Thought in Syriac and Arabic in the First Millennium CE

This project explores the metamorphoses of Greek Christian thought in Syriac and Arabic during the first millennium CE, a period of significant cultural exchange and intellectual transformation. Despite its importance, Syriac Christianity remains little-known today, and its role in shaping the cultural dynamics of Late Antiquity is poorly understood. To address this knowledge gap, our project aims to illuminate Syriac and Christian Arabic sources, define the religious identity of Syriac Christians, and create open-access digital editions of Syriac florilegia (anthologies). By studying the writings of Syriac and Christian Arabic authors, we will uncover the significance of Syriac florilegia as cultural creativity laboratories and their impact on the patristic canon period (2nd-6th centuries). Our groundbreaking endeavors will produce digital editions of Syriac florilegia from the 8th-10th centuries and study neglected writings of Syriac and Christian Arabic authors from the 8th-11th centuries. The research outcomes will improve our understanding of cultural dynamics in Late Antiquity, highlight the role of patristic Christianity as a bridge between European and Middle Eastern intellectual history, and inform current religious discourses in Europe while preserving the endangered cultural heritage of Syriac Christians.
